case_vignette:
A healthy 12-month-old infant girl presents with a yellowish-orange papule on the right upper extremity. Her mother first noticed this lesion approximately 6 months earlier. It has never bled, ulcerated, or formed blisters. The infant does not scratch the lesion nor appears otherwise bothered by it. However, when the lesion is rubbed, it appears to swell and turn bright red. On physical examination, there is a soft, oval-shaped, yellowish papule with a peripheral rim of erythema on the right extensor forearm. The lesion is approximately 1 cm in diameter. The infant's mother reports that the infant has been otherwise healthy and has had no recent illnesses. The infant's family history is unremarkable. The infant's physical examination is otherwise normal. The infant's mother is concerned that the infant may have a skin cancer, but the infant's pediatrician has reassured her that the lesion is likely benign.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
Hello! I have a yellowish-orange bump on my right upper arm that swells and turns bright red when rubbed.
How long have you had this bump on your arm?
I first noticed the bump about 6 months ago.
Has the size of the bump changed since you first noticed it?
No, the size of the bump has not changed since I first noticed it.
Do you experience any pain or itching from the bump?
No, I do not experience any pain or itching from the bump.
Do you have a personal or family history of skin cancer?
No, my family history is unremarkable, and I've been otherwise healthy.
Do you have any other similar bumps elsewhere on your body?
No, I do not have any other similar bumps elsewhere on my body.
Final Diagnosis: Juvenile Xanthogranuloma

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents with a yellowish-orange bump on their right upper arm, which has been present for about six months. The bump swells and turns a bright red color when rubbed. Despite its appearance, the bump has not changed in size since it was first noticed. The patient reports no pain or itching associated with the bump, and has no significant family medical history to note. The patient also confirms being otherwise healthy and does not have similar bumps elsewhere on their body.
